networking_calico/plugins/ml2/drivers/ca.message:
As you're passing the whole subnet dict here, can you put the logic to check subnet['enable_dhcp'] inside _update_dhcp_port?

I think that would be cleaner than having an optional 'delete' arg.

I'm not sure this logic is robust if there are multiple concurrent subnet updates being handled by different instances of the Neutron server.

I think it would be more robust to reread all of the DHCP-enabled subnets that are now associated with the network ID, and add a fixed IP entry for each subnet that doesn't already have one, and delete fixed IP entries for any subnet IDs that are no longer associated.

I think there are probably update_subnet_postcommit cases where the subnet already existed and was already DHCP-enabled (e.g. adding a host route), and so the dhcp_port will already have a fixed IP for the subnet.

Autocorrect?  Not sure where that came from.

Not the same - a conjunction is the joining of two things, and a conjugation is the set of verb tenses for a verb; "go, went, going, have gone, will go, will have gone" is the conjugation of the word "to go" in English.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
So this is where the actual issue is. This is defined here:

  https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/16.0.0/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L902-L921

This calls 'nova.virt.libvirt.guest.Guest.delete_configuration' with a special option, as seen here:

  https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/16.0.0/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L907

This special option determines whether the NVRAM is deleted or not.

  https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/16.0.0/nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py#L270-L271

So what we actually want to do is to stop setting that flag for *all* cases where we have UEFI. Instead, we only want to set it when we call '_undefine_domain' with UEFI when we're *not* rebooting. This would probably necessitate passing a new parameter to '_undefine_domain'

This difference between this change and original is that it raises ComputeResourcesUnavailable other than BuildAbortException when catching ComputeResourcesUnavailable exception, and this is the place that the patch will fix.

this function is widely used, are we sure 
the exception we adds will fit for all scenario ?

Currently, ComputeResourcesUnavailable will be raised in claim operations,such as rebuild_claim, resize_claim, instance_claim. When the exception is raised，nova just check that whether there are enough resources, and doesn't do actually operations in hypervisor, so I think we can ignore this exception and rollback instance to its original vm_state.

Here also, if we get far enough to stop an ACTIVE instance and then spawn below fails, reverting the status to ACTIVE is wrong since the guest would be STOPPED.

Given how broad rebuild can fail it's likely best to just let the instance go to ERROR status. The only way to probably use the errors_out_instance_on_exception context manager properly with rebuild is marking which exceptions can rollback the status using InstanceFaultRollback exceptions, like in _prep_resize.

This may not be correct in all cases. For example, let's say the instance is ACTIVE when you start the rebuild and we got far enough to destroy it but then spawn failed. It would be incorrect to mark it as ACTIVE again if the guest is dead.

How about

  If you still have question, you can contact us on the ``#openstack-nova`` IRC
  channel or via the discuss@openstack.org mailing list

> How about
 > 
 > If you still have question, you can contact us on the
 > ``#openstack-nova`` IRC
 > channel or via the discuss@openstack.org mailing list

by using the [nova] tag in the subject of your mail.
This is pretty open-ended, what one person thinks is a trivial change could be a nasty mess if they aren't aware of side effects, e.g. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/638629/

refactor

Also, refactor and feature implementation are weird to lump together here, generally a refactor should be low impact, unless you're confusing refactor with redesign. When I think of refactor, I think of cleaning up code that should be covered by existing tests, i.e. method decomposition.

I think what you're trying to say above is:

 Changes to the nova repository fall into three categories:

 - Bug fixes <link to lp dashboard or bug how-to page>
 - Nonfunctional improvements such as
   - Additional tests
   - Documentation
   - Enhancements to code readability and maintainability
     (refactoring/simplification, removal of dead code, etc.)
   - Trivial changes, e.g. clarifying code comments or fixing
     typographical errors in log/error messages
 - Features <link to rfe/bp/spec process>

LGTM.
In addition, I'd like to put `Features <link to rfe/bp/spec process>` first before Bug fixes.

Need to add the following section here:
Protocol Specific Authentication Parameters
-------------------------------------------
The WSMAN and Redfish protocols require different parameters to be set on the node in Ironic to be able to communicate with the bare metal node.
The WSMAN protocol requires the following parameters:
* ``drac_username``: The WSMAN user name to use when communicating with the iDRAC. Usually ``root``.
* ``drac_password``: The password for the WSMAN user to use when communicating with the iDRAC.
* ``drac_address``: The IP address of the iDRAC.
The Redfish protocol requires the following parameters:
* ``redfish_username``: The Redfish user name to use when communicating with the iDRAC. Usually ``root``.
* ``redfish_password``: The password for the Redfish user to use when communicating with the iDRAC.
* ``redfish_address``: The URL to the Redfish service running on the iDRAC in the form: "https://<IP>".
* ``redfish_system_id``: The Redfish ID of the server to be managed. This should always be: ``/redfish/v1/Systems/System.Embedded.1``.

If using only interfaces configured to use WSMAN (``idrac-wsman``), then only the WSMAN parameters must be supplied.  If using only interfaces configured to use Redfish (``idrac-redfish``) the only the Redfish parameters must be supplied.  If using a mix of interfaces where some use WSMAN and some use Redfish, both the WSMAN and Redfish parameters must be supplied.

hooks/neutron_api_context.py.message: I think that instead of raising an exception we should rather put the charm in the 'blocked' state, so that the proper message is displayed in the output of 'juju status'.

Please create a doc of this method in the following format:

    def is_valid_ipv4_prefix_size(prefix_size):
    """
    Validates whether the value of the prefix_size is
    a multiple of 8, with maximum value of 24 and minimum
    value of 8.

    :param prefix_size: IPv4 subnet prefix size
    :ptype prefix_size: int
    :returns: Validation result
    :rtype: bool
    """

Unfortunately this is not an effective way of communicating this issue back to the charm user; the status will be overridden by the assess_status call which is performed at the end of every hook execution.

We have a pattern for this in newer reactive charms, but not for classic charms like this one; a potential solution might be to record the list of configuration options with invalid values globally as part of hook execution, and then write a handler as part of assess_status that reads these values and sets an appropriate message - something like:

blocked - 

Invalid configuration: ipv6-ptr-zone-prefix-size, ipv4-ptr-zone-prefix-size

not providing the detail is fine - that's what the doc on the config.yaml is for IMHO.

Logging a full message to the debug log on the same basis as your 'e' variables would be good to complement the status message.

keystone/identity/core.py.message: suggest moving these to inside the 'if driver.is_sql:' statement to improve efficiency. For LDAP driver, no need to perform the unnecessary lookups.
according to this if any group is associated with the domain backed by ldap, we wont delete that group and directly delete domain?
This sounds weird. Do we mirror LDAP groups in Keystone? If not, why are there any LDAP groups in Keystone to delete?

Maybe this discussion will help provide context: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-keystone/%23openstack-keystone.2019-10-15.log.html#t2019-10-15T14:58:20

Groups are the same as users, see below for how we handle them when the domain is deleted. A domain is the namespace for users and groups, and normally when we delete a domain there are notifications emitted and we try to clean up everything owned by that domain - projects, users, roles, and groups. But users and groups are part of a different driver than projects and roles. If we try to delete a user that is *owned* by the domain but *backed* by LDAP, we get an error because we can't write to LDAP. Same with groups.
I see. Thanks for the context.
ahhh ok. Thanks for sharing the logs.

etc/proxy-server.conf-sample.message: No need for "should". This is not an RFC. Describe what the implementation does in a firm and positive way. I suspect you reserve this language in case another middleware decides not to comply. I think we have the power to be strict about it.

I think your last sentence hits at the heart of the issue. We have no power to strict it. If a middleware create a container with `x-storage-policy: wrongpolicy` there's nothing we can do, at least I can't see how we could enforce it, but open to ideas.
and I mean third-party middleware, not swift core middleware (those we have the power to be strict about it).
This is in the DEFAULT section, it's by design then that it "falls through" to the s3api filter section?

I wonder if the default here should be false, and derive from the primary container.
Why? I'd suspect in the new world be it MPU or new versioning whereby users don't get a choice in the "backend" container (ie it's invisible to them), they'd expect it to be the primary.

Ie. If uploading a large object to EC because I care about the space, I don't want all it's segments to be replicated.. that's why I'm using an EC storage policy. Maybe my MPU understanding is wrong.
But this is the same for the new versioning. If we're going to create a "shadow container" to hold the versions and then point at the correct version with a symlink. Then as a user when I'm putting my object in an EC (for example) container, and it happens to be versioned, I want my data to be just that EC, no matter where it lives behind the scene.

Otherwise I could image problems, what about data sovereignty, where some of my "data" must be say in Oz, but my default policy is global.. ops.. my data leaked.

In my mind, I think we should always default to primary container.. but maybe it's just me :)

Per the other point, if we are using our existing "opendev" tooling for deploy certificates, etc. I think we make a clean break.  In the same way, it's not too much effort to make vhosts from templates in ansible either.  This is reflected in the next update.

We've designed the opendev.org infrastructure from the ground up to be scalable and gitops-driven.  Due to the co-management of the openstack.org zone with the foundation, it's difficult to enact the same kind of automation (and incurs a significant extra cost).  The most straightforward thing that aligns with our efforts there would be to migrate these documents to an opendev.org url, eg docs.opendev.org/openstack/governance.

I think we decided to use CNAME redirects on the _acme-challenge domains to get us half-way ... we use our certificate generation and renewal process for legacy sites in RAX, until such time there is impetus for openstack.org to switch completely.  This is reflected in next update.

docs.starlingx.io as well? (files.o.o just already serves it from AFS currently, but it's in a similar state to the openstack.org subdomains and may help reiterate the multi-domain nature of the problem we need to solve)

I think that this makes a good home for things currently served by files.o.o (zuul-ci too?).  But my feeling is that we have enough just getting this to work.

I feel like once these sites have all the framework in place, moving things from files.o.o is not a spec-level process but just a few easy reviews.  So I feel like migration of things there can be tackled at a future point.

Maybe airshipit.org at some point but we currently don't host anything for it aside from a git redirect. I mentioned starlingx.io because we host static content for their docs site (granted on files.o.o for now). I didn't bring up zuul-ci.org as it's already under OpenDev's DNS management so does not require the CNAME effort. Just trying to indicate that it's not only openstack.org sites which would be able to take advantage of the CNAME plan for SSL cert management.

Similar to comment above, I think we'll have a natural consolidation point after the initial implementation for these other services, but the initial migration will provide the template that makes it easy.

What I meant by "Other domains" was that new projects coming under the opendev umbrella would be using opendev nameservers
and airshipit.org? I think we can loosen the "other domains" statement below if it turns out the existing domains on rax aren't moving quickly?
Any particular reason for the server name change?
Do you mean why call it "static" and not "files"?  If so I feel like "static" reflects it's nature as a static web host serving from AFS, where as "files" is a bit catch-all.

I think we need a "service" name here.  We don't ever want to have to update the openstack.org dns after we set this up, so we should have any numeric hostnames there.  In the future, we may want to replace static01 with static02, or load balance across static01..static0N.  We need to be able to do that without updating all of the names that point to the server.

So in DNS we should have:

  tarballs.openstack.org. IN CNAME static.opendev.org.
  static.opendev.org IN CNAME static01.opendev.org.

Or the second could be replaced by one or more A/AAAA records in the load-balancing scenario.
Oh, yep, we had discussed that as a component of this plan and I didn't notice it was missing here. Totally agree, thanks!

> I think we need a "service" name here.

Yep; the current CNAMEs point to just "static.openstack.org" and I had intended to maintain the same model, however you're right it should be called out.

Update adds work items to set that up, and makes it clear in here this it the model to follow.
